content.body: (I know the harness is a horrible hack, but it was done as such to get it working somewhat in all browsers, inc. Firefox just after the HTML5 Parser merge which had some odd, fun bug)
it's great
roc: Try running a single test case in it :)
can't remember half his gripes with it, but he has plenty
foolip: does Opera fire the progress event on video elements?
nessy: yes, as per spec about the timing
last I checked anyway :)
yeah - about to write you a bug report :)
I think onprogress works, but not addEventListener
but then, it's really hard to test because after every test I have to change the file name, because Opera has buffered it and a shift-reload doesn't reload the video resource
I have the same problem with Chrome, incidentally
that's at least one bug ;)
actually - ditch that - it's only the reloading that doesn't work
progress events work
nessy: use a HTTP server and set the source to URL+'?'+something random
good idea
is it Math.random() perhaps?
still, it would be nice if shift-reload on the page ditched the buffered media resource
anyway, that's what zcorpan does
Firefox does that
Opera doesn't have a special reload I think
at least I never found one
well, I can reload the resource with shift-click on the reload button
also, I can remove all other elements from cache in "Tools"->"Delete private data…"
except for media resources
oh, that *is* a bug
can you file one at http://bugs.opera.com ?
ok
and webkit is next …. :(
gah, seems impossible for me to get an account there :(
will try the wizard ...

we like standards, etc etc :)
MikeSmith: less than all other browsers?
hehe
jwm: inversely proportional
little-known axiom

foolip: ok. fun :)
foolip: if i go back to video work, i still have a reason to go to göteborg then :P
foolip: You are moving? That's sad :(
Well I mean it is hopefully nice for you
I'm quite thrilled
zcorpan_: you're always welcome to work on video
To be leaving Linköping?
jgraham: Honestly, yes. Outside of work there's nothing I enjoy about Linköping.
Well yeah I would hardly recommend it as a holiday destination
Most importantly, I think my wife will like Göteborg better.
More people. People are rare in Sweden...
Not stockholm then?
No, Stockholm is the capital and thus clearly sucks, as I am not from the capital.
That's the theory anyway :)
Also, they talk funny.
That makes no sense
foolip, that goes for all of Sweden, I have to say
Haha
they talk funny in göteborg too
Is there an Opera office in Stockholm?
But sure Göteborg is nice

hsivonen: yes
ok
there's an office in örebro also
a tinier one
zcorpan_: You don't count as "an office"
jgraham: :(
One person is "working from home" You need two people to make an office
Unless you are actually not working from home I guess
if Rijk is actually in wijk bij duurstede maybe we should petition for a Dutch office here in Utrecht
I wonder what version number I should give to the next release of the V.nu parser...
It should be 1.3 at minimum and I don't want to go all the way to 2.0 yet
possible choices: 1.3, 1.5 and 1.9
just do 1.3 then
you're not in competition (yet) so there's no reason to inflate your numbers
annevk: ok. makes sense
I'm thinking of going to 2.0 when I add a sanitizer
Make it converge on the golden ratio

for sure our marketing department has their highlights

zcorpan_: hey!

IRI checking
MikeSmith: i know
ah, OK

is eating websocket cookies
ok, no oproblem
*problem (no o)
zcorpan_: yeah, I figured you were still in Websocket Wonderland for a while
is sort of curious what Hixie is up to
is sort of curious what the chairs are up to
wonders if the chairs noticed that Gecko, WebKit and Dreamweaver made progress on implementing elements proposed for removal since the start of the survey
at least one of them should have noticed stuff landing in WebKit :)
not to suggest that that's in any way relevant to Decisions, of course. ;-)
depending on the outcome of the decision, we may have came up with a few more <embed>-like elements
with as difference that these have a proper specification
annevk: do you mean elements supported by browsers and Adobe's authoring tools but not the spec?
damned browsers making up their own tags
hsivonen, yeah
with "the spec" being the "the spec the W3C publishes"
If these decisions don't keep the elements then the HTMLWG deserves to become a laughing stock
You can't really blame the WG for chair decisions, can you? Well, and the people who create the issues.
You can blame the WG for putting up with it
We could have a revolution
The W3C and the chairs only have authority because people choose to give it to them
With pitchforks and torches and things
Revolution is XHTML2
Although those typically end with the revolutionary leader dyning in an unpleasant way, so if anyone asks it was Philip`'s idea
Though from a W3C perspective maybe HTML5 is indeed revolution... Strange world.
*dying
annevk: That depends on what you revolt _against_
You could say XHTML2 was a revolution against HTML, and HTML5 is a revolution against XHTML2
What if you just wanna evolve?
The WG members could form a new working group that's entirely independent of the W3C with its own non-consensus model for making decisions and that develops its own specification called HTML5
That's a question of authority, I suppose
and so it's their fault if they choose to work within the existing system instead
From the W3C viewpoint, I'm sure XHTML2 _was_ evolution
From miles high it may indeed seem that way
i liked xhtml2's "hx"
using h1 (etc) in conjunction with nested sections is sorta weird
AlexD keeps it up: "HTML5 is vapourware _until_ the spec. reaches recommendation status."
aho: Yeah but it is kinda broken because you can still use <h> and <h1> in the same document
vapourware: "New software that has been announced or marketed but has not been produced."
This is like the opposite of vapourware
We haven't announce it is done but it is still beiong produced
jgraham, still... i'd like to point out that this is a section-nesting heading and not a regular one
solidware?
aho: They are all just headings
using a weight-free heading would do the trick
Guess I should stop... http://xkcd.com/386/
jgraham, yea... they are all just tags (?) :>
i just liked that there was some heading which indicated that its intended weight depends on the section nesting
aho: Isn't that obvious, though? Since h1 would only be at the very top of the document normally
and tables are normally only used for tabular data? :D
aho, by that argument we should have <table2> which will be only used correctly, which of course is nonsense
Dashiva: I think something like LiquidCrystalWare would be better since it appears all over the place but the theory is still not complete
bad analogy :>
(of course the theory of any state of matter is not complete but...)
aho, works for me :)
you know, if the svgwg thinks html5 is vapourware, maybe we should just use the same process as svg 1.2 did
and just stamp html5 as a REC and ignore 10% of the feedback we've gotten, just like they did
http://ln.hixie.ch/?start=1155235213&count=1
Hixie: The rules don't apply to XML languages, you should know that by now
html5 has an xml serialisation!
A fig leaf, nothing more
annevk, "Sections may contain headings of any rank, but authors are strongly encouraged to either use only h1  elements, or to use elements of the appropriate rank  for the section's nesting level."
if there were an element for headings without any weight, it would be clear which route you picked
It would be clear, but for what purpose?
say there is a doc... and 5 years later some different person writes a new stylesheet
No problem at all
there is also no problem with using single letter variables exclusively
it just takes a bit longer to understand than necessary
There's a rather significant backwards compatibility problem, for no actual benefit
aho, just use <h1>
<h2-6> is only if you care about backwards compatibility
if you use canvas and all those new apis... why would you care about such a small detail?
indeed
why do you?
breaking backward copatibility of weight-free headings, that is
Because not every page uses canvas?
article, aside, section, nav... they "break" backwards compatibility the same way
not really much harm done there
Those are different. They _add_ semantics to what is considered meaningless by older browsers
well, i did like h/hx. that's all :P
being able to differenciate between weighted headings and weight-free/section-nesting headings doesn't add anything?
nope
wouldn't that make the structure clearer?
You're the one claiming it does, shouldn't you answer?
<Dashiva> aho: Isn't that obvious, though? Since h1 would only be at the very top of the document normally
Hixie: Last link in that blog post is dead, by the way
well, imo h/hx:h1-h6 is sorta like span:em/b/strong/i
i really liked that
but it's not like this will be added to any spec any time soon
Dashiva: that's even better
Dashiva: so much for stable links at the w3c!
so, i don't really see why you think it's necessary to discuss this in depth
Maybe it wasn't cool enough to not change
aho: Span has no semantics, the proposed hx does.
yes
h/hx on its own doesn't have specific weight
sorta like a td on its own doesn't have much use :>
I guess you're just an aho, after all...
*clap* *clap*
Dashiva, Hixie, I guess it is http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/CR-SVGMobile12-20060810/lc3-replies-public.html

Dashiva, if you see some hx somewhere, you know it's a heading which relies on section-wrapping. if you see h1, it's either the old kind of heading *or* one which relies on section-wrapping. the hx element doesn't have this kind of ambiguity - and that's something i generally like
e.g. i like code conventions, because they help getting rid of that stuff
saves time
aho: I have no idea how you envison that working
What happens with <body><hx><section><hx><section<h1>
(ignore the typo)
Is the <h1> a top level heading or a third level heading
(exactly this use case happens any time a mashup embeds content that uses <h1> in a container that uses <section>)
what happens in a mashup that embeds content that uses <h2-6> in a container that uses section? ;>
it would just work
so, that section h4 thing you just embedded will look like what exactly?
aho: The logical outline is well defined
aho: The style will (by default) just depend on the tag name, but that is a CSS limitation taht would be worse if we also had <hx>
Hopefully we will get ::section(n) and so on
-moz-any() is nice for this stuff .)
e.g. section any(h1,h2,h3,h4,h5,h6,hx) { first level heading}
if it all were hx you wouldn't have to do that though
Right, but make the section a pseudo class that matches all level one sections
aho: It can't all be <hx>
why not? (if we ignore mashups)
We don't ignore mashups
If we make invalid assumptions we can prove anything
i never used any mashup, i never made one, i never will make one
i don't even know one popular mashup
If you aren't making mashups, it's pretty much a non-issue
You never used an online feed reader, for example?
Mashups are the important case, not something to ignore
aggregators typically process the feeds quite a bit, but they generally don't really work all that well
"process the feeds quite a bit" typically means "do some sanitization". Having to rewrite the heading tags to fit in with the output template is rather different
well, currently you just have random headings there
i don't really see how that's super awesome
in retrospect i think it would have been better if i hadn't mentioned xhtml2's hx. i hadn't expected this kind of annoying discussion... giving that it's a dead spec n all... oh well :>
it's nice that html5 picked up section tho (there! i said it) :>
notes "WebM will be supported by all three major browsers: Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox and Opera" on OMG! UBUNTU!
I'm still wondering what Apple will do with WebM
no word on that I'm assuming?
(Next to Steve Jobs saying he doesn't like it)
Of course he doesn't like it, it wasn't invited by him :)
Peter`, Apple won't support WebM while there is still a percieved risk of patent trolls
Clearity on the legal patent subjects might take months, if not years
they will at least be waiting to see what comes out of the FUD from the MPEG LA, if anything at all. But, they'll likely just maintain the threat for ages, like they have with Theora.
right, so I wouldn't recommend holding your breath for Apple to support it.
Lachy: citation needed
I'm quite curious about the future and implementation of WebM, specifically now Microsoft is more or less supporting it as well
but I believe there will at least be 3rd party quick time components made available one day, which will enable support in Safari.
Apple doesn't even support Vorbis yet, so any official support for VP8 seems incredibly unlikely.

But following Theora and the lack of a formal stance of the company on WebM, different from Steve Jobs' own thoughts, it's still somewhat undefined right now. As hsivonen already said, while it's unlikely, nothing is clear
It's so frustrating that XiphQT still doesn't have Thusnelda. it would be nice to have WebM support rolled into XiphQT
Peter`: what have I said?
"citation needed"
hsivonen, http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/05/20/jobs_on_vp8/
http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/05/21/mpegla_mulls_patent_license_for_webm/
Peter`: I meant I wanted to see Lachy's source
Lachy: thanks
Lachy: I think the Register is extrapolating quite a bit from Steve dropping one URL without commentary
yes, that's true. But it's not too much of a stretch given what Jobs previously said about forming a patent pool around open video codecs

There was another article I read that was a set of email exchanges between a reporter, Larry Horn from the MPEG LA and, I believe, someone from Xiph, which talked about the FUD that the MPEG LA have maintained for years over theora
hsivonen: alright, sorry :)
Lachy: well, yeah, anyone can be "looking into" whatever
(As I understand it, the FUD Monty was referring to wasn't MPEG-LA FUD per se but FUD from the MPEG camp. IIRC, MP3 licenses haven't been managed by MPEG-LA.)

I'm assuming Google knows what they're doing though, also considering the list of companies who already committed to VP8, there has to be a certain degree of certainty. A chance of submarine patents arising always remains, with any product that's entering an already-existing market
when creating a Ubuntu USB installation stick with a large (over 1 GB) persistence file, is the creation of the persistence file supposed to be insanely slow?
I'm wondering if I have bought a bad USB stick
also, it seem the progress meter was programmed by the person who came up with the Windows file copy progress meter

Peter`, IANAL, but I think the number of other companies supporting WebM, many of whom I assume hold numerous patents of their own, give some level of protection because they may hold patents that they can use defensively against others who aggressively attack VP8
http://twitter.com/microft/statuses/15176790401

Lachy: That's a good point, specifically given that the license states that you cannot file patent claims against Google if you're using the specification. Widely interpreted, one could say that they're using open-source to minimize the chance of patent claims
Then again, IANAL either

Are webgl and notifications likely to become official html?
I know that Chrome either has them or is implementing them.  Can't speak for other browsers.
WebGL will remain a separate spec, and so will notifications
It makes little sense to make them part of the HTML spec, IMO
But I guess it's a question of what you mean by "official HTML"
I meant html as defined by w3c, but I think that I got my answer.
